And going back to the first question of exportability of the U.K. restructuring plans, I believe that we are – we have to restructure our business every time our expense ratio is not in line or better than the competition, and so we have plans in different geographies when our expense ratios are not in line or better than the competition.
We'll take a question on the phone since we have, I think, some of them.
, please go ahead.
Yes. Good afternoon. Do you hear me?
Yes.

Okay. I have a couple of little question if I may. My first question is on yield of – yielding of the assets, how you look at P&C globally, you have stable financial revenue, providing an investment yield of 4.6%. So – and that is the opposite on the Life side because I find out that there is a strong decline which is logic – more logic I would say, from 5.8 to 3.6 on an annualized basis. So could you comment on this and especially on the P&C side, what can we focus on H2?

And on this question I would like to link a little add-up on the slide 28 of the appendix, there is a focus on the corporate bonds, not CDS, which is quite interesting and I would like to have a comment, is the market value divided by the CDS book is increasing while in the same time – from 2.4% to 3.3%, while in the same time spread has come down, so this is not logic. So this is on yield on the assets.
On – I have a second question on VA business. A lot have been said on the U.S., but you're apparently resizing your strategy out of the U.S. So if we could have some flavor also there?

I have a third little question on the embedded value. Obviously it's too early, but as I understand you did some early calculation. And since end of '08 situation has changed dramatically in some field, it was a negative 104 – it was a negative adjustment of more than 20 billion end of last year. So could we have a first idea of – given a market consistent approach where we could stand today given the fall of the volatility and the spread in particular and the recovery of the equity market also?

And last question is for Henri maybe. You're very well positioned to rebound from where we are, to bridge a link with 2003 now you have only 1% invested assets in equities. So how can you benefit from the recovery of markets? Thank you.

Okay. Navin, I will start with the last part of your question and then we'll take the other one. You should read the appendixes more carefully because we don't have 1% of equities, I mean we have more than that...
Name the page.
The page...
Yeah. But hedging down doesn't mean that we don't have the upside, Jean. We have all the upside on those equities.

And second point, the exposure to the upside is not only through the equities we have on the balance sheet. May I remind you that the unit-linked business and the asset management, are businesses where you benefit from the upside much more strongly than through the exposure you have on the balance sheet itself through the commissions we are taking.

As I've taken the last question, I will take the question. I don't understand why you say that we are resizing our strategy on VAs. We are redesigning the products, re-pricing some of them, but I don't see what has changed other than that. And I'll let my friends and colleagues answer the other ones in the order they want.

For the first question in fact in P&C the – we have an underlying investment yield in the first half of 4.3%, which was slightly down 0.2%. In Life we were around 4.2%, down 0.5%. So, where does it come from? It comes mainly from the fact that normally in the past years, you had higher investment yield in the first half due to the dividends and dividends were significantly lower. At the same time, we have been investing, you remember during the course of the first half, at interest rates which were much lower than they are today.

As far as your second question is concerned on the CDS, you know most of the CDS that we have been using, you remember we explained in the – at the end of last year that CDS was an alternative for us to invest in corporate bonds. We are investing in – and mostly in Japan. So we have JGB's and we invest in – we sold CDS in order to create entity corporate bonds. But pay attention, since we have three months – we closed the books at the end of March in Japan. So that means that all the recovery from the CDS market which – with the quick tightening of the spread, is not in the books yet.
So even though this table says June 30 for Japan which represents, probably 6 billion out of the...
Japan represents, yes roughly.
Roughly 6 billion out of the 12, in fact it's March 31 data.
Very good. We don't have any other question on the phone?
We have no further question.
Very good. No other questions in the room? Fine, thank you very much.
